question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
Let
$P_2=\{ \alpha_0+ \alpha_1t+\alpha_2t^2: \alpha_j \in \mathbb{R} (j=0,1,2) \}$
be the set of all polynomials of degree at most 2.

Show that the transformation $T:P_2 \to P_2$ is a linear transformation,
where $T(f(t)))=(t+1)\frac{\mathrm{d} f(t)}{\mathrm{d} x}$.
sols:
Note that differentiation is a linear operator

$f(t),g(t)\in P_2$ and some scalar c

\begin{align*}
T( f(t)+ g(t) ) &= (1+t)\frac{\mathrm{d}(g(t)+f(t)) }{\mathrm{d} t}\\
&= (1+t)\frac{\mathrm{d}f(t)) }{\mathrm{d} t}+(1+t)\frac{\mathrm{d}g(t)) }{\mathrm{d} t}\\
&= T(g(t))+T(f(t))
\end{align*}

and

\begin{align*}
T(cf(t))&= (1+t)\frac{\mathrm{d} cf(t)}{\mathrm{d} t}\\
&= (1+t)c\frac{\mathrm{d} f(t)}{\mathrm{d} t}\\
&= cT(f(t)))
\end{align*}

Thus as

$T( f(t)+ g(t) )=T(g(t))+T(f(t))$

and

$T(cf(t))=cT(f(t)))$

we see that \emph{T} is a linear transformation.
